supporting_quotes:
Years of service
1947–1975
Scowcroft received his undergraduate degree and commission in the United States Army Air Forces from the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York, in June 1947
events.notes: Role inferred from context as undergraduate student

supporting_quotes: He served in a variety of operational and administrative positions from 1948 to 1953.

As a senior officer, General Scowcroft was assigned to Headquarters U.S. Air Force in the office of the Deputy Chief of Staff, Plans and Operations, and served in the Long Range Planning Division, Directorate of Doctrine, Concepts and Objectives from 1964 to 1966.

events.canonical_org_name: Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs
supporting_quotes: He next attended the National War College at Fort McNair, followed by assignment in July 1968 to the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs.
events.notes: Role inferred from context as staff member

roles: Deputy Assistant for National Security Council Matters
supporting_quotes: In September 1969, he was reassigned to Headquarters U.S. Air Force in the Directorate of Plans as Deputy Assistant for National Security Council Matters.

roles: Special Assistant to the Director of the Joint Staff
supporting_quotes: In March 1970 he joined the Joint Chiefs of Staff organization and became the Special Assistant to the Director of the Joint Staff.
Scowcroft was appointed Military Assistant to the President in February 1972;

roles: Deputy Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs
supporting_quotes: and was reassigned as Deputy Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs in January 1973.

National Security Advisor
1975–1977
Before joining the Bush administration, Scowcroft was vice chairman of Kissinger Associates.

National Security Advisor
1989–1993

events.canonical_org_name: Blue Ribbon Commission on America's Nuclear Future
supporting_quotes: He was appointed Co-Chair of the Blue Ribbon Commission on America's Nuclear Future from 2010 to 2012 alongside Lee Hamilton.
Scowcroft was the founder and president of The Forum for International Policy, a think tank.
He was also president of The Scowcroft Group, an international business consulting firm.
He was co-chair, along with Joseph Nye, of the Aspen Strategy Group.

He was a member of the Inter-American Dialogue, Trilateral Commission, and the Council on Foreign Relations and a board member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the Atlantic Council.

He was a member of the Inter-American Dialogue, Trilateral Commission, and the Council on Foreign Relations and a board member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the Atlantic Council.

He was a member of the Inter-American Dialogue, Trilateral Commission, and the Council on Foreign Relations and a board member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the Atlantic Council.

events.canonical_name: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS)
supporting_quotes: He was a member of the Inter-American Dialogue, Trilateral Commission, and the Council on Foreign Relations and a board member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the Atlantic Council.

He was a member of the Inter-American Dialogue, Trilateral Commission, and the Council on Foreign Relations and a board member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the Atlantic Council.
In 1988, he received the Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement.
President George H. W. Bush presented him with the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1991.
In 1993, he was created an Honorary Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace.
events.notes: No organization specified for this award

supporting_quotes: In 2005, Scowcroft was awarded the William Oliver Baker Award by the Intelligence and National Security Alliance.
